I made this to beef up the other end of my old iphone cable which is showing its age.  The 30pin end is supported with Zaggo's dock:
www.thingiverse.com/thing:1279
This is one the first things I have created since switching to Alibre for my designing.  Compared to the multitude of mesh modelers out there I am very happy moving to a full solid modeling program and love the parametric nature of it.  Highly recommended Alibre!
I also very much like the extra gripping cutouts I placed on the sides.  I dont know about others but I find yarding the little connector out from the USB port on the backside of my computer more difficult then it needs to be...seems like the designer was looking to make life harder then needed when they not only made the plug as small as possible but also gave it a mirror smooth finish!  Sure looked pretty, but I dig the beefy look of its new body ;).

Print out 2 copies, trim around the studs a little as I can never seem to get the wee 3mm pins to print perfectly square, throw a little glue between the halves and squeeze it together.  I made the iphone cord hole a little larger then necessary as I was unsure how good my alignment pins would work (amazingly well actually, despite the trimming I needed to do the case halves aligned perfectly)!

The idea of being able to print with two different filaments at the same time with the SmartrapCore is very tempting… I'm working on it (it's nothing more than a work in progress, I didn't test it for real yet), with the goal of making the minimum possible change to the printer itself. So far, it seems promising, as there are only three new pieces to make : the slideX big piece to hold the two heads, a new hotends fan and Zsensor support, and (if you like) a new printing zone cooling fanduct.

Update (oct. 5 2015) : I redesigned the whole thing, to allow a very necessary adjustment of hot ends relative height, plus a few extra modifications and improvements. Can't tell yet if it's really functionnal, I just printed the parts and didn't find, so far, the time to test them in actual double filament printing.

Update (V. 5.0, dec. 12 2015) : many improvements, mostly about cooling (hot ends and printing zone), but most important : I added 8mm rods support! Pick the slideX that fits your setup, and there you go… ;)
Also, you can have the regular 40mm fanduct or the (much better) two parts fanduct for radial fan. Both use the same fixation system, you can use either one on the same slideX.

Update (V. 5.1, june 23 2016) : several little changes, mostly on the mobile dual head support, to improve its stability, make it easier to insert GT2, also on the front part (dual hotends fan support) so that the Zsensor support part will be easier to print, main slideX body part, also to improve the stability of the moving part, and the fanduct bottom part of the printing zone radial fan cooling system, to improve the shape and make it easier to print. The mobile dual head support part has some tiny material support included in the STL file to ease the printing process. That's really easy to remove before use. Other than that, no material support whatsoever is need to print this whole thing. Also, I left only the printing zone cooling system with radial fan, because it's definitely the best fan type and you'll really need that for a clean dual extrusion! ;)

You'll need, of course, a second hot end with the exact same dimensions, extra pneufit, extra Bowden, and an extra extruder, which means another stepmotor, hobbed bolt, bearings etc.
Also, the 40mm hot end cooling fan will be replaced by a 50mm one, which will be exactly the right size to cool down the twin head (you can use the spare 40mm for the printing zone cooling system with the new fanduct).
Then, a few M3 bolts (35, 20, 16mm) and as many nuts.
Oh… and also a second roll of filament, of course ! ;)

comments.text:
Hi, thanks for your comment. :)
This is really nothing more than a work in progress, and I don't have the slightest idea if it actually can work with that design, as I don't have yet the elements (a second hot end and another complete extruder, to begin with) to complete it in order to make any real life test. So… it's even less possible for me to know what to do to make a 8mm version of that.
So far, it's a very compact and tight design with 6mm rods, so I'm not even sure it could be possible to extent that to a 8mm rods system, but I hope it is, of course.
I make all my designs in Blender, I don't use any CAD software. Would the Blender source file be alright for you ?

description.text:
2-piece Mikrokopter external compass housing for mounting with 25 mm tube-clamp.

Features:

  • Direction-arrow
  • M3 thread in top-part to secure top to buttom via aluminium screw (non-magnetic)
  • M3 thread in lower part to secure to clamp
  • Holes for stress-relief zip-tie for the compass communication cables
  • Guide-notches to prevent rotation and wrong mounting of top part to lower part

As this Thing features rather tiny screw-threads, be sure to print it using a low layer-height, and with slow extruder-speed.

Don't have enough counter or table space to stash all of your filament spools? Tired of taking out the rod of your current holder just to get a spool every time you want to change filament? Well then just print out a few of these, add a spanner rod and your problems are solved! Each bracket screws into a wall stud and can support multiple spools of your favorite filament! 2 Brackets across studs 16" on center will hold 6 - 1kg filament spools. Please see instructions for more details. Happy Printing!!

Each bracket is designed to be attached to a wall stud with 2 - 1/4" x 2" lag screws. The hole for the spanner rod is 9/16" in diameter to allow for a 1/2" piece of tubing to be easily inserted and held in place by the .5in Retainer part. After I printed 3 brackets I realized I had a 3/8" stainless steel rod laying around so I made bushings that take up the slack in the hole and keep it firmly into place. I included that .stl file also in case anyone has the same idea.

The brackets were printed in PLA, flat with a scale of 10 (In Cura 15.04), along with 3 layers and 30% infill for strength and no supports.

author: moliver2810

description.text:
This is a simple way to cool your filament post-extrusion making tricky prints a little easier. Yes, it's a bit ugly... I'd bet yours could be cleaner, I'm just always in a hurry. It works - although I had a bit of a struggle to get great comparison photos, since things printed pretty well with it on and off. Definitely better on, though! BE CAREFUL! I haven't used this long-term and I don't know if the silicone tubing will stand up to heat over time. I might put a layer of actual insulation between the tube and hot end (ZOLTEK! PYRON!)... I do know the tubing deformed on the first print, but it just made it fit the hot end better, it didn't melt or burn... so might be OK even without the insulation. BEFORE/AFTER PHOTO NOTES:
  • Printed on my Prusa, using a Makergear .35mm hot end.
  • Using 25-50mm/sec acceleration in Sprinter firmware.

REQUIREMENTS: 1) Aquarium pump
2) Silicone aquarium tubing
3) Bits of kapton tape or other high-temperature tape I think you can get an idea how it goes from the photos. The only tricky things I did were:
  • Cut a notch into the side of the tube facing the hot end, so it can be pulled a little closer in and angled more by the kapton
  • Make an effort to angle the ends in a bit, by applying the kapton in a sort of V pattern.
  • Make sure you've got a bit of clearance above the hot end! You don't need much.
  • Where the kapton is not directly supporting something, think of it like the skirt on a hovercraft. It will be full of swirling air; take advantage of this.
  • Angle each tube end /very slightly/ clockwise or counterclockwise to maximize the air vortex created under the kapton skirt.

comments.text: Just for the record, I just finished a 3hour plus print and it's still fine, so I don't believe it's going to burn or melt down.

title: Double Bowden Extruder for Aluminium Extrusion 20x20

description.text:
What is it?

Double extruder for alluminium extrusions Profil 5 20x20, usually used on most of DIY CoreXY Printers, with possibility to move the area of bearing-spool contact up to 10° (see pictures), in case you need to print Nylon, Flexible materials and so.

Does it work?

I still have no idea since i've never printed it, gonna try it out as soon as possible and write down a feedback in case it works (hope so).

What do you need for it?

  • 2xStepper Motor Nema17/23 dimensions
  • 2xHeatsink (it's not necessary)
  • 2x608ZZ bearing
  • 2xDirect drive gear
  • 12xM3x30mm cilindric head (ø7mm head) bolts
  • 2xM8x20mm max head width 5.5mm screws
  • 2xM8 nuts
  • 2xBearing_Pusher.stl
  • 1xRight.stl
  • 1xLeft.stl

    ..and of course a printer with allumiunium extrusions, or make a support to mount it in somewhere else.


Feel free to comment, ask, and (whynot?) to try it out leaving a feedback so to optimize project.

It needs one 6mm 3ft long smooth rod down the center, and 3mm screws to attach the body pieces together, and to hold the fins in place. The fin assemblies should be 4 inches tall when printed. title: USB power bank, using 2x18650 Li-ion batterys

description.text:
Power bank using again cigarette lighter type usb charger. There are 2 versions, round and more bulky, all other dimensions are same.

Added versions with external 5mm LED hole.

What you need:

-Plastic Battery Storage Case Box Holder For 2 x 18650
-rocker switch 9x13 (smaller one)
-suitable usb charger with LED, like shown on the images.

Unfortunately I can't tell what is good and what's not. Most this type chargers keeps inside basic regulators and using them with under voltage should be just fine, but remember source voltage must be at least 1.5V higher than output ( 5V). Connecting wires should be easy task, simple solder wires directly to charger metal contacts, no need for anything clever things and remember to connect switch to complete circuit.

Other solution is hack car charger to pieces and use only usb connector with led and solder directly 5V regulator to connector, 7805 should do the trick.

What I like to enhance is find somewhere display to show how much power is left. It would be really nice to show 0-100% and connecting this display behind push button for fast reading. Still looking suitable measurement display.

If you don't know what you are doing, don't do it!

author: alterfettersack

description.text:
FilamentChallenge

Features:
Sturdy
Highly Printable assembly
Three strand guide system
Three position locking selector head
Spring loaded anti-reverse spooling mechanism
Built in flush cut razor

Requires:
¾” PVC about 1’ for 3 spool holder
½” PVC about 2’ for 3 spool holder
Gel super glue for assembly
1 Small spring (.49” long x.162” OD)
Printed parts

This is a sturdy multi-part spool holder that assembles using three PVC sections, some super glue, a tone of printed parts and one small spring. It’s intended to hold 3 spools at a time so that all filament strands can be run through the selector head. The selector head rests on top of a multi-part arm and base and has a built in spring loaded anti-reverse spooling mechanism. This mechanism uses the force of the spring to add resistance to the filament strands causing them to require a little more pull from your stepper motor (not enough to cause problems) but making it less likely to allow the stand back through to reverse the spool, overlapping filament and causing snags. Once the filament goes through this section all but one strand is stopped by the selector head with the built in razor. When you want a new spool, simply push the one in use back while holding the spring loaded button until its only sticking out as much as you want to cut off. Then turn the head to the right until it clicks into a new position and cuts off the old head. Then push the new filament through and run it into your printer.

Melt your old plastic lures and pour them into these molds. Use a high layer count so it won't deform when you pour in the hot plastic.

Make the tail first. Fill "Tail mold - 1" and cap it with "Tail mold - 2". Some plastic should ooze out, this can be trimmed later.

Squeeze the cured tail into the slot of the body mold. 1/4" of the tail should be inside the body. Pour the hot plastic onto this part of the tail to fill the body mold. This will help adhere the 2 parts.

There are 2 different body styles.

Use Spam or veggie oil to help release the cured plastic. Takes 10 - 15 mins to cure.

Use a 4 or 5 keel weighted hook texas rigged.

Retrieve slowly just below the surface to get the body to wobble.

Retrieve a bit faster on the surface and get the tail to flutter and create a wake.

STP files are included so you can modify the molds. PLEASE SHARE.

title: Prusa i3 Z carriage for M8 lead screw

description.text:
Didnt like the idea of regular threaded rod and didnt like the way the nut was retained. So I changed the end carriages to use an M8 acme leadscrew and brass nut thats readily available on Ebay from multiple sellers.

Also includes a modified tensioner bracket. works with a 1/4-20 square head bolt. bolt is inserted from the inside and a hex nut or threaded thumb wheel is added on the outside for tension adjustment.

EDIT 9-6-15

I had to remove the idler bracket. the bore for the linear bearing was the wrong dimension. I will upload a corrected part later tonight. i apologize for the inconvenience.

EDIT 9-14-15

Added missing and fixed idler bracket .stl file
Designed in Solid Edge ST7

A ventilated jar, suitable for garlic or maybe small onions, etc.

Update 2-17-17
It worked great for months while in a cupboard. Garlic was fresh like new. But while moving things I left it out for a couple days, partially exposed to artificial light. The garlic sprouted very long shoots as if it couldn't wait to do so.
This thing is handy if you have nothing better, but a keeper really needs to be opaque. Keep it out of the light or buy or make a ceramic one.
,,,,,
Garlic and onions last longest in a cool, dark place, and with just enough ventilation to prevent mold.

Half way through this print I realized the red color transmits a lot of light. Black is more opaque, and may be better suited, but a print will never approach the environment afforded by a clay garlic pot.

In any case, I wouldn't leave a plastic one on a window sill or anywhere out in the open. I plan to park this inside a cabinet. If the garlic doesn't sprout in a couple of months I'll be happy.

It was intended to be spacious and still fit on this Afinia's 5.5 x 5.5 inch platform. The 5x5x5 inch pot will hold maybe 10 or 12 medium size heads of garlic.

jar 3hrs 46min, 105 grams ABS.
lid 61 minutes, 31 grams
Afinia defaults. Except that in the software's Print Window / Preferences / Support / Area, the selection was "20 mm2". That means openings with an area less than 20mm squared will not have support, and there was no support to remove from the air holes.

Things vibrated a lot, particularly toward the end, and the wide tall print may require the extra adhesion a raft provides. Better safe than sorry.

The files are SAE. For metric scale up by a factor of 25.4,
Or scale both parts by whatever is appropriate if you want it larger or smaller than the original. The lid is a loose fit so precision is not too critical.

I assume your printer is an Afinia. If not, be aware the Afinia H479 is (or was) probably the fastest stock printer available.
comments.author: chils41

comments.text:
Thanks for quick reply. Taking your advice I went with 0.3 layer height and it cut the build time good 3 hours.
Depending on the printer you may or may not want to print the support. My printer's bed only move in Z direction, so vibration is not huge issue, and I think it will print nicer if I did not print any support.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
You're welcome again.
I try to be practical about layer thickness.
Default thickness on the Afinia is 0.2mm. But while that requires an additional 50% more time, there's not a lot of difference in strength or in appearance. If the project requires fine detail, or if there are other good reasons for thin layers, then I will do it. Otherwise I will go with 0.3mm.

It holds five AAA batteries, so with NiMH(1.2v) you will get 6v or with alkaline or zinc batteries(1.5v) you will get 7.5 volts. I made so a wire can be ran through the holes.
Also you can put a piece of cloth through one of the side holes to make a way to pull the batteries out.

It uses a better technique (thanks to profounddevices). See the picture with the bright yellow post it on it... ( also here: http://www.thingiverse.com/derivative:1634 ). You can screw a nut onto the PTFE, which creates a very good connection. The extruder drive mechanism and/or hot end have to be designed with a T-slot to fit this Bowden cable. ============ Here's a video of it being printed: (first iteration, a bit coarse quality since I reduced backlash in my Darwin frame while I forgot to reduce it in my software backlash compensation algorithm)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ddmB9ScSbQ This is a holder for a 4.67 mm PTFE cable that serves as a guide for the filament. The plastic feedstock will travel from a driving mechanism to the extrusion head, through this flexible tube. The PTFE, a.k.a. Teflon, a very low friction. This solution will allow you to have multiple extruders on your machine without the moving mass becoming too heavy. The lighter it is, the quicker you can move the heads, e.g. when you're not extruding. The machine will need less current to run the motors, it reduces stringing when not extruding. Even more so, it reduces the weight of the X-axis so much that a much simpler and lighter Cartesian bot is possible. The steel rods wouldn\'t necessarily be needed, allowing a much larger ratio of self-replication. The Bowden cable itself could be printed in several modules that snap together. This guide could be lined with telfon-tape (available in every hardware store) that can be replaced when worn. It has one major drawback. The need for a control mechanism that accounts for pressure on the filament is needed. The tube is a bit flexible, and so is the plastic filament. This makes the assembly a bit springy. But when you use a flow-control system that accounts for pressure, you will end up with much better quality. The extrusion starts and stops very sharply. You can do this by pulling back after extruding a segment. After that, you push it in as much as you pulled it back and simply start extruding again. You do need stepper based extrusion to adequately be able to control how much the filament is pushed into the extruder and pulled back out. The concept of using a Bowden cable as guide was suggested and pioneered by Ed Sells. See his post here:
http://blog.reprap.org/2009/04/bowden-extruder-concept.html

The PTFE tube has such a low friction, that you can hardly attach it to anything. The holder is long so that you have a maximum contact surface. There can be a lot of force on the filament, so it needs to have a really tight friction fit and needs to be glued in place. You should make little grooves or cuts into the PTFE, being careful not to go through the material. When you've made it as rough as possible, put glue on it and push it into this cable holder. Make sure the glue is fully cured/set before using the cable. Let the glue set for at least one night, just to be on the safe side.
You can twist the two outer holes to fit over two bolts. On the one side, this should fit on a Darwin-compatible extruder. On the other end, it should fit on a driving mechanism that fits on the same thing. You can also use two of these to connect two Bowden cables together, so you're able to extend them or use multiple combinations of length.
Update: The version 5 files have no holes in them.

description.text:
A small puzzle I have in real life - I decided to make a SCAD model of it as an exercise and hoping that someone would print it.
It has been printed by ScribbleJ with good results, photos are at http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/5927996270/in/photostream/. v2 has evenly spaced spheres, this improves the shape of the solved puzzle.
There are thick cylinders (parametric, default 1.5mm) through the spheres that should be connected.
There is also a set of thinner cylinders (also parametric, default 0.1mm) that keeps the whole thing together so you can keep it as a 4x5 grid of spheres (perhaps for gifts or something)

author: nathan7

description.text: Bitbeam is a 3d printable, LEGO Technic-compatible construction system. More info at http://bitbeam.org Use this shaft encoder wheel to measure the rotation of a wheel. (You'll also need an LED and a phototransistor.) Shaft encoders are especially useful when using a DC motor for motion. DC motors are cheap and wonderful for making little robots move, but DC motors do not come with a built-in feedback mechanism for precision control. Shaft encoders are a great way to get that feedback. For an explanation on how to use shaft encoders in your projects, I recommend Fred Martin's book "Robotic Explorations".

In the download, I've included both a printable STL and the original OpenSCAD source code.  
If you use this with infrared LEDs and phototransistors, be sure to print this in black or other dark color. Through trial and error, I noticed the encoder sensing did not work when the wheel was printed in natural (light-colored) ABS.

Fits 1 (one)  HC-SR04 UltraSonic Module sensor in a 4x2x6 Brick.  This mount is intended to hold up a HC-SR04 Sensor for prototyping some ideas.  
The brick itself is equal to 4 (2x6) Lego bricks. So it can be "bricked" into a nice support structure to hold it in place.  
A huge help when you are trying to make something and don't want your sensors out and loose. That can cause shorts, pulled wires,  or just slow you down.  
This brick was specifically designed to hold the HC-SR04 UltraSonic Module sensor.  
If you don't have a 3D printer but you're interested in getting one of these we can print you one at www.badbrick.com/catalog

Quality: Layer Height = 0.2 and I increase the temp to 240C to let the little larger prints fuse better. All other defaults are the same.

Another version of a CNC Router Clamp. It is designed for 1/4in. T-Nuts or Inserts in your waste board. I use 1/4in. all-thread for the pivot post and a 3in x 1/4in. bolt for the other. This version has smaller thumb screws and has a foot for the end bolt to protect your waste board. I printed the clamp at .2 layer thickness and 50% infill the other parts are printed at .3 layer thickness and 10% infill.

comments.text: Any chance of a m8 version?
comments.author: smitad

comments.text: This does look really good, but seems like it has a lot more detail to the curves than you will ever see.  Have you tried exporting this at different resolution settings?  I took a look at 001_Clamp.stl file & the facets on your curves are from .14mm to .2mm.  Look at a metric scale & see if you could really see that small a difference.  In openscad, I generally keep my facets down to .7mm to 1mm & that still maybe over kill.  Another advantage of having less detail is your slicer does not have to look through as much data to slice the object.  I do like this design & may print one to see how it looks.
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text: I always save my stl files at the highest resolution I can.  When these are printed, the edge rounds,do not show in the prints, but they do eliminate most, if not all, of the compression overhang that occurs on the first and last layers printed, thus eliminating cleanup of those edges.  These files slice quickly, print great and require no cleanup. Designspark creates very clean geometry, so when sliced, I never get slicer errors, so the process goes quickly.
comments.author: GeoDave

comments.text: looks realy good
comments.author: WernerSch

comments.text: I used the free program, Designspark Mechanical to model this. all edges have a .5mm round on them plus the program has a high resolution stl exporter option. The program can be downloaded here ... http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical. It is a very simple to use program with many tutorial videos on youtube

title: Hybrid Rocket Engine (Lite Saber Engine i1)

description.text:
This is a project to build a hybrid rocket engine for a rocket I will someday build and launch in the desert. The idea is to design a good powerful engine, then stack an repeat into a 9 engine configuration for a replica SpaceX Falcon 9 Rocket.

The reason for the name is due to the appearance of the first model that was painted silver and looked like a light saber from star wars.

I will upload video as I go
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tsifklldMpU&feature=youtu.be

Test 1
Setup
Engine-iteration one chamber and injector
Nozzle-version one nozzle
Fuel-propane starter and roofing tar grain
Oxidizer-Nitrous Oxide "whip it's"

Hypothesis: propane burn will start the burning of the tar fuel grain, then we will introduce NOS and cut off the propane and react the fuel grain and oxidizer.

Results: the fuel grain never ignited. The propane and the oxidizer reacted outside the nozzle, a flashback occurred due to oxidizer and fuel mixing prior to entering the combustion chamber. The concrete nozzle held up great, and the ABS outer body was cool to the touch.

Lessons learned: I had a misunderstanding about how the oxidizer and the fuel should begin reacting, and that the injector can't have fuel and oxidizer coming out of one hole, (stupid oversight) and if you want two gasses going into the combustion chamber they need to be injected separately. I also thought NOS was safer than GOX which is not true. I decided to only use GOX or gaseous oxygen with the tar fuel grain and begin the ignition/reaction with a stick soaked in denatured alcohol.

Test 2
Setup:
Engine-iteration one chamber and injector
Nozzle-version one nozzle
Fuel-roofing tar grain then "Shoe Goo" grain
Oxidizer-GOX Gaseous Oxygen (2,300psi welding tank) running at 200 psi max.

Hypothesis: after watching several videos on YouTube and research into oxidizes I felt I understood what I was doing for the first time. I though I would get combustion to actually happen inside the combustion chamber and that I would not get any flash back. I was hoping to achieve the matchstick pattern coming out of the nozzle.

Results:
The engine ignited perfectly, the fuel burned away very quickly. When going to refuel I realized that the compacted bentonite clay combustion chamber came un-compacted and the ABS outer wall was soft. I reloaded it anyway and loaded wet shoe goo for the final phase of the second test. The burn was so bright I saw white spots, and it was over pretty fast. The concrete nozzle failed the hole was 3/16 or so and ended up at 5/16 or more. The test was pretty exciting though.
I achieved combustion in the combustion chamber, there were no flashback issues and I did not get the focused exhaust matchstick pattern.

Lessons learned:
-The combustion chamber should be made of concrete like the nozzle that was rock hard after all the firing and dropping it on the ground with no cracks or breaking.
-the combustion chamber needs to be bigger to accommodate more fuel and pressure.
-I need a powerful proven fuel grain that is consistent throughout all the tests, so I can focus on one variable at a time like nozzle shape.

Test 3
Has not occurred yet

Engine-Iteration 2 (3x larger in physical size, and 6x larger in power capacity)
Combustion chamber-Gen. TWO
Injector-Gen. TWO
Nozzle-Gen. TWO nozzle
Fuel-PMMA Acrylic rod 1" diameter with 1/4" hole 6" lengths in a chamber that can handle 12" lengths.
Oxidizer-GOX Gaseous Oxygen (2,300psi welding tank) running at 200 psi max.

comments.text: In the photos, it looks like you are running air through the system?
comments.author: dacb

comments.text:
NOS or Nitrous Oxide, in the form of whip cream cartridges "Whip it's" Not a very great solution, I guess I'll just have to huff the rest of these like back in high school :) Just kidding.
I am using GOX now or Gaseous Oxygen, in a 20 cubic ft canister at 2,300 PSI, No more messing around. GOX is good for testing purposes because its safer than NOS. If I optimize the engine design and decide to stack these into an actual rocket I'll use NOS.
comments.author: dacb

author: bjorntm

title: Office breaktime kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The OBTK (Office Breaktime Kit) provides you with a construction toolkit that will turn idle time into a break that will improve productivity right after. It also allows organizing social activities and it therefore can contribute to team building if that is permitted and/or feasible under cover in your organization. You also can encourage trading and competition: Who can come up with a new toy / engine / exhibit or design a sliding game (tip: use whiteboard markers on your desk) ? Finally, squezzy elements can be used to prevent wrist tendinitis.

According to old-style management literature, most folks seem to "spend time inappropriately" at work, on a daily basis. Surfing on the Internet (either using work computers or private cell phones) seems to be most popular. Others rather defend the idea that workers need breaktime. In today's IT-intensive environments, idling on the Internet (e.g. worrying about FB status, new job opportunities and such) is not a good idea. Breaktime should be used to do something that is relaxing, fun and rather physical. Idle time should clear the mind, not clog it !

There are 6 elements which can be combined into various objects

  • a half sphere with a hole, can also sit upside down
  • an asymmetric wheel, can be used as support for a ball
  • a beam with 4 + 3 holes, for constructing engines
  • a short stick rounded on one side, for gluing, tip, and as handle
  • a long stick rounded on one side, for gluing and as tip/handle
  • a long stick that is thinner in the middle, i.e. an axle for the wheels

From these 6 elements people at your workplace can assemble various devices like spinning tops, table curling stones, bowling balls and pins, yoyos, wheels of fortune, racing cars, and more. Alternatively, they also could create stunning works of art (e.g. a black apple sandwich with a raspberry filling). This kit is also suitable for kids of an age where they stop swallowing little sticks.

The idea for creating this set came to me by "accident" after playing around with Arnitel (a very strong flexible filament) of which I bought a roll 2 years ago but had forgotten about (see http://edutechwiki.unige.ch/en/Arnitel for some information). I started playing with creating a squeezy half sphere and then wanted to make something that would allow playing with it. Since I also teach a bit of 3D printing and since it's always nice to be able to justify time spent on 3D printing in my office, I came up with the challenge of create a minimalist (but hopefully successful) construction kit that would allow to create cool little devices from just a few elements. Once I was done, I remembered that as a kid I played with "Matador" (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matador_(toy)).

All objects are very easy to print. There are only two challenges:

  • Print as precisely and nicely as possible
  • Prevent warping with plastics like ABS or Arnitel

Sticks: I suggest printing most sticks with flexible filament (e.g. Arnitel). Use strong fills for PLA (50%) and 10-50% for ABS or Arnitel. I used a raft for Arnitel stick printing, since it lessens the chance of having it ripped off the platform after some irregularity. With flexible plastic and PLA I suggest printing two sticks at a time. Else it may not cool enough between layers...

Wheels and half spheres: Print with any plastic and any fill (between 10-20% is probably best). Use only 5% filling for flexible plastic. Put "office" glue (e.g. "Pritt Power") on the platform for Arnitel or ABS, since the beam, half sphere and wheel will try to warp. Remove the glue before printing with PLA or it will stick too much !

Beam: I suggest either using ABS (or equivalent), or PLA with a strong fill (50%). ABS will have a strong tendency to warp, but the horizontal holes should help preventing this. Add more holes if you cannot use glue...

All-in-one: I don't suggest printing this because I'd change both plastic and slicer settings for sticks, the beam and the two larger objects...

Print speed and resolution can be anything. I suggest some kind of "medium 2.5mm layers" and 80mm/s for good quality. Printing much faster is also possible ....

Calibration:

Print a half-sphere, a beam and a long stick. If the long stick doesn't fit (after filing), make it smaller or larger. Creating construction kits with "normal" printers and slicers is quite difficult. Every setting (printer model, printer calibration, slicer settings, plastic, etc.) will produce slight variations. My models use the same width for holes and sticks that should fit inside since I observed that sticks somewhat shrink with my current setup...

OpenSCAD file:

It is somewhat parametrized code (disclaimer: I am not a programmer). You easily can calibrate the sticks. Making more radical changes, e.g. print everything on a smaller scale would require some re-coding or at least testing (which I did not).

I Saw a few similar ones on here for flies, but our problem here is wasps, i also adapted it to be able to have a string run through it so it could be hung from a tree...

EDIT: I just added V2, i found V1 did work, but it wasn't a smooth and a little tighter on the jar than i wanted. I recently learned how to do threads, so i recreated it entirely around the threads i found worked well on the jar, so V2 is a complete rebuild from the threads out, i think it fits a lot better.

EDIT again: I made a V3, i thought the cone in V2 was too thick, so i narrowed it in V3, takes like 3.5M less filament and almost an hour less print time now at 100% fill

And again: i dont know how to leave things alone, this is V4, i made it with little handles on the outside instead of the holes in the previous version which would allow the liquid to leak out the threads if it was tipped over, i am sure this one wont be leakproof, but it should be a lot better.

Now you can print his great design for your reel sizes.

Shamelessly entered into the contest for the customizer part. The design is all dagomas. The customizer in this case is a simple re-usable pattern for resizing all works where only an STL file is available. Converted first to OpenSCAD then patterned to rescale and provide a customizer UI.

After reprinting at a smaller size I realised the numbers were a little out. The original was designed for a 52mm spool. I misread that as 53mm. The original did give a nice snug fit though, so I measure the inner diameter with digital calipers on my reel and got the number 51.55. This new baseline is in the latest online customer and files so if you've downloaded this already and have a slightly less snug fit than you'd like, you should get the new version.

Video here: https://youtu.be/KyGRl6ujfBc

title: Hook for rotating car air conditioner vent holder mount support for Samsung cell phone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hook replacement for a generic rotating car air conditioner vent holder mount support for Samsung cell phones. It could be compatible for other identical supports used for different brands. You can check the pictures to be sure if hook would fit ok (4 screws needed).

The piece was designed by a friend of mine, Edu G. for replace the broken original one. Thanks to him for his design expertise and patience with my recommendations during the test printings.

The piece has been printed with PLA 1.75 filament using Cura slicer software with a 0.4 mm nozzle. I got better results choosing these main settings:

  • Layer height: 0.2 mm
  • Shell thickness: 0.4 mm
  • Support type: "Everywhere" (Structure type: Grid - Fill amount: 25%).
  • Platform adhesion type: Brim

I recommend choosing a platform adhesion to avoid defects in the first layers of the lower ring due to its thinness that could difficult the attachment of the entire structure . Please check pictures to see how it is. However you will obtain the best result for this lower ring if flip 180º the piece, but the need of printing supports makes you will get a base with worse finish.

description.text:
This robust stand has adjustable X and Y heights, allowing you to use USB microscopes for larger items.

The stand also offers enhanced stability when taking pictures with the snapshot button, cleverly manages the USB cord, and is adjustable for left and right-handed users.

The stand was developed for Plugable's USB2 250x microscope http://plugable.com/products/usb2-micro-250x.

I highly recommend printing it at at least 50% infill, 100% is best. This makes the stand heavier and improves it's stability.

Here's a blog post detailing more of the features and design process: http://plugable.com/2015/09/03/robust-and-adjustable-stand-for-plugables-250x-usb-microscope

Designed in SolidWorks.

Sized to print on a 6x6x6 inch bed.
Print at 100% infill. 50% is lowest you should go if print time is a big issue.
Print the arm piece with a brim to make sure it sticks to bed.

PHIL is my fully printable universal filament holder. PHIL knows how to hold filament because PHIL is made of filament.

I've included a few design sketches in the upload. I poked around Thingiverse for design inspiration and considered making a few existing designs customizable using OpenSCAD. In the end I decided to make something unique and 100% printed.

I've tested the spool holder with Makerbot ABS, small PLA, large PLA, and various other generic spools. By spreading out or rotating your two PHILs you should be able to accommodate any size spool.

I put some stick on rubber feet on my PHILs because I have a slippery desk. You can also use 3M Command Strips to hold PHIL down if necessary. Lastly, I've included mounting holes for screws on the bottom of PHIL if you'd like a slightly more permanent installation.

Thanks to TBuser for the great pin library I used to make PHIL spin.

Update 9/20/15: I've added the source Trimble SketchUp file for those users with print tolerance issues. Hopefully scaling the spools slightly larger or smaller should help with tightness/looseness issues.

My spools printed on the tight side, but the longer I spun them the easier they turned. Now they spin like matchbox car wheels!

For a two-tone PHIL switch filaments at the following mm layer heights:

  • 0-3 Black
  • 3-10 Red
  • 10-13 Black
  • 13-End Red

After printing snap all the parts together and fill PHIL with filament.

comments.text: I read the comments before trying this one; thought I could make it work better with the addition of a base plate to stabilize it. Gave it every chance I could, including smooth rods rather than the plastic pins, hoping I'd be able to come back here with some positive suggestions...but after two days of messing with it I've admitted defeat, it's just too small for a full-size (~1 KG) spool due to the constraints of printing it with the M3D Micro, and the spool-rim support system doesn't work as well as any of the center-spindle setups I've used. Even putting the spools on common shafts, it's too difficult to make all four points of contact with the spool rim bear equal load. Spend your time & filament on making a spool center insert instead. If you must have a desktop solution consider Mark Wheadon's submission; my workbench has an upper shelf which makes it easy to suspend all of my filament spools using easily-made expendable wire coat-hanger loops.

description.text:
This is my first attempt to create a "soap bubble box". My girlfriend came up to that idea, but you may see this thing as an inspiration: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3449 It may need some updates, though. The hole where you put the wand might be too big, but can be filled with hot glue. I thought: better too big than too small. ;)
The cap fits too strong on the box. You may need to adjust the scad file or to sand down enough plastic. Otherwise you may distribute the water in it when trying to open it. ;) And do not try to "sand" it by turning the cap against the box in a quick manner - this produced a lot heat and melt both pieces together. That happened to me (stupid guy, I know. Should have known that heating-issue... ). ;)

• Print one piece of "Seifenblase Deckel" (cap).
  • Print one piece of "Seifenblase Dose" (box).
  • Print one piece of "Seifenblase Stab" (wand).
  • Sand the conenction between box and cap until it fits easily.
  • Hot glue the wand into the box.
  • Have fun. ;)
    • I would really appreciate any help in how to make a winding, so that the cap can be winded onto the box. I did not managed to get that.
Here is the repaired Boston Bruins case. Apparently the scaling is off slightly on the S4 model; scaling by 0.96 should make it fit the phone much better.

print with the fan side down without any support.
40mm fan.
the second version has a bigger hole for more airflow.
aluminium tape prevents the print from melting.

comments.text: Is the aluminum tape actually necessary? I'd imagine it doesn't do that much actually. Aluminum is a good conductor of heat. I guess it would somewhat prevent a small point source from concentrating heat in one spot. But have you operated this rig without the foil? (I don't have foil handy)
comments.author: doc

comments.text:
i print it with pla and on the thinner section behind the nozzle it get quite soft wen you heat up the extruder for some minuts without turn on the fan.
if the fan always is on it cools from the inside and it is no problem.
comments.author: doc

author: carllosdaniell

title: Buffalo Sabres Galaxy S4 Phone Case

description.text: Here is the repaired Buffalo Sabres case.  If you print this and there is anything in the logo that doesn't turn out or isn't supported enough please leave a message and I will repair the model as soon as possible. Apparently the scaling is off slightly on the S4 model; scaling by 0.96 should make it fit the phone much better.

comments.text: Hey instead of spamming the site with a million different iterations of it, how about just uploading them all to one part?
comments.author: IcanCwhatUsay

comments.text: Didn't think of that, this is my first set of 3D models I've made.  I was planning on making NFL cases as well so I'll do that for that them, thanks for the suggestion
comments.author: IcanCwhatUsay
